title: The Real Estate/Financial Complex
descriptions:
Here is a 293-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Real Estate/Financial Complex

This project proposes to investigate the underexamined relationships between real estate, finance, and state involvement, with a focus on the period from 2007 onwards. Despite their interconnectedness, these fields have been studied in isolation, neglecting the critical connections between them. Our research aims to bridge this gap by introducing the concept of the "Real Estate/Financial Complex," which highlights the intricate web of relationships between these domains.

The project consists of three research components. A postdoctoral researcher will conduct internationally comparative research on quantitative and qualitative shifts in the complex. Three PhD students will each investigate national mappings of the complex in two countries, as well as local/urban case studies. The Principal Investigator will focus on the qualitative shift towards real estate, finance, and the role of the state, the global dimensions of the complex, and the conceptualization of the complex.

By adopting a multidisciplinary approach, this project will provide a comprehensive understanding of the Real Estate/Financial Complex, its evolution, and its implications. Our research will shed light on the ways in which these interactions shape economic outcomes, influence policy decisions, and impact societal welfare. The project's findings will contribute to the development of more effective policies and regulations, ultimately promoting a more stable and equitable economic environment.

Here is a 293-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Real Estate/Financial Complex

This proposal seeks to investigate the understudied relationships between real estate, finance, and state involvement, and to develop a new conceptual framework for understanding these interactions. The project will explore the connections between these three areas, examining how they intersect and influence one another at multiple scales, from local to global.

The research will be conducted through a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative and qualitative data. A postdoctoral researcher will conduct internationally comparative research on the quantitative and qualitative shifts in the real estate/financial complex, while three PhD students will focus on national mappings of the complex and local/urban case studies in six countries. The Principal Investigator will focus on the qualitative shift towards real estate, finance, and the role of the state, as well as the global dimensions of the complex and the conceptualization of the real estate/financial complex as a metaphor.

The proposed project addresses a significant research gap in the existing literature, which has largely overlooked the connections between real estate, finance, and states. By centering attention on these interactions, this project aims to provide new insights into the ways in which these three areas shape and are shaped by one another. The findings of this research will have important implications for our understanding of the complex relationships between real estate, finance, and states, and will inform policy and practice in these areas.

Here is a 293-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Real Estate/Financial Complex

This proposal seeks to investigate the understudied connections between real estate, finance, and state involvement, with a focus on the period from 2007 onwards. Despite their significant impact on the global economy, the interplay between these sectors remains poorly understood, particularly across different scales and geographical contexts. The proposed project aims to fill this research gap by introducing the concept of the "real estate/financial complex," a metaphor that highlights the intricate relationships between these domains.

The project will consist of several interconnected components. A postdoctoral researcher will conduct internationally comparative research on quantitative and qualitative shifts in the real estate/financial complex. Three PhD students will be recruited to conduct national mappings of the complex and local/urban case studies, with each student focusing on two countries. The Principal Investigator will focus on the qualitative shift towards real estate, finance, and the role of the state, as well as the global dimensions of the complex and its conceptualization.

By exploring the real estate/financial complex through a mixed-methods approach, this project will provide a nuanced understanding of the ways in which these sectors interact and influence each other, ultimately informing policy decisions and contributing to a more stable and equitable global economy. The proposed research has the potential to make a significant impact on our understanding of the complex relationships between real estate, finance, and the state, and will contribute to the development of new theoretical frameworks and methodologies in this area.
